articles.headline: Internet Puts a Sugarcoat on Scalping
articles.snippet: The Internet has taught major league sports teams that scalping was never really the problem. The problem has been the ridiculous amount of effort expended trying to stamp it out.
articles.abstract: The Internet has taught major league sports teams that scalping was never really the problem. The problem has been the ridiculous amount of effort expended trying to stamp it out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big games tomorrow. Green Bay against the Giants at Lambeau Field. New England versus San Diego in Foxborough. Winners go to the Super Bowl. Big, big games.

articles.headline: Bush Proposing $145 Billion Plan to Spur Economy
articles.snippet: Congressional Democrats, in a rare show of bipartisanship, pledged to work with the president to enact a plan quickly.
articles.abstract: Congressional Democrats, in a rare show of bipartisanship, pledged to work with the president to enact a plan quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush called Friday for roughly $145 billion in tax relief for individuals and businesses that he said would “provide a shot in the arm” for the economy, while Congressional Democrats, in a rare show of Washington bipartisanship, pledged to work with him to enact a plan quickly.

articles.headline: Economists Debate the Quickest Cure
articles.snippet: Recession-fighting measures will help if they come quickly, experts say, but there is disagreement over which policies would have the greatest impact.
articles.abstract: Recession-fighting measures will help if they come quickly, experts say, but there is disagreement over which policies would have the greatest impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In trying to assemble a bipartisan package to jolt the slumping economy, the White House and Congress have turned to familiar tools that experts say have worked in the past. But there is also a lively debate among economists about which measures will best accomplish the goal.
articles.byline: By Steven R. Weisman and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Lawyer Reveals Secret, Toppling Death Sentence
articles.snippet: A lawyer who believed that prosecutors had committed misconduct stayed silent for 10 years due to ethics rules.
articles.abstract: A lawyer who believed that prosecutors had committed misconduct stayed silent for 10 years due to ethics rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 10 years, Leslie P. Smith, a Virginia lawyer, reluctantly kept a secret because the authorities on legal ethics told him he had no choice, even though his information could save the life of a man on death row, one whose case had led to a landmark Supreme Court decision.

articles.headline: Seeking Tools to Calm a Market
articles.snippet: While the market has taken deeper dives in the past, volatility is approaching its highest levels in several years.
articles.abstract: While the market has taken deeper dives in the past, volatility is approaching its highest levels in several years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dow 6,000 or Dow 14,000?

articles.headline: Sprint’s Customer Erosion Prompts Cutbacks
articles.snippet: Shares of Sprint dropped 25 percent after the company said that it planned to lay off 4,000 workers and close stores to trim costs as its customer base shrinks.
articles.abstract: Shares of Sprint dropped 25 percent after the company said that it planned to lay off 4,000 workers and close stores to trim costs as its customer base shrinks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sprint Nextel’s announcement on Friday that it is losing customers more rapidly than expected is making investors nervous about a weak economy’s effect on other wireless companies.

articles.headline: A New, Global Oil Quandary: Costly Fuel Means Costly Calories
articles.snippet: Demand for biofuels has created tension between using land to produce fuel and using it for food.
articles.abstract: Demand for biofuels has created tension between using land to produce fuel and using it for food.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUANTAN, Malaysia  Rising prices for cooking oil are forcing residents of Asia’s largest slum, in Mumbai, India, to ration every drop. Bakeries in the United States are fretting over higher shortening costs. And here in Malaysia, brand-new factories built to convert vegetable oil into diesel sit idle, their owners unable to afford the raw material.

articles.headline: Job Data Passes Threshold Where Recessions Dwell
articles.snippet: When the number of Americans out of work starts to rise sharply, a recession occurs. By that token, the latest figure for unemployed workers is, at the least, a danger sign.
articles.abstract: When the number of Americans out of work starts to rise sharply, a recession occurs. By that token, the latest figure for unemployed workers is, at the least, a danger sign.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the number of Americans out of work starts to rise sharply, a recession occurs.

articles.headline: Between Pulpit and Podium, Huckabee Straddles Fine Line
articles.snippet: Mike Huckabee is trying to fire up fellow evangelical Christians without unnerving other voters.
articles.abstract: Mike Huckabee is trying to fire up fellow evangelical Christians without unnerving other voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  Mike Huckabee mentioned his faith only glancingly in his stump speech this week at North Greenville University in Tigerville, S.C. Discussing presidential decisions that will matter after he is long gone, he added: “By the way, I have made arrangements for what happens after that, and it’s all good. It’s all good.”
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Michael Powell

articles.headline: Back to Roots, G.M. and Toyota Trade Places Again
articles.snippet: A shift in focus over the last year by the world’s two largest automakers reveals how each is working on their own version of a turnaround.
articles.abstract: A shift in focus over the last year by the world’s two largest automakers reveals how each is working on their own version of a turnaround.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  At last year’s auto show here, General Motors and Toyota Motor seemed to be trying to steal each other’s core customers. G.M. unveiled the Chevrolet Volt, a hybrid-electric concept car, to bolster its green credentials. And Toyota took the wraps off its huge new Tundra, which has a big V-8.

articles.headline: Overseas Investors Buy Aggressively in U.S.
articles.snippet: Foreign investors are buying at a record pace, taking advantage of American duress and a weak dollar.
articles.abstract: Foreign investors are buying at a record pace, taking advantage of American duress and a weak dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, a Saudi Arabian conglomerate bought a Massachusetts plastics maker. In November, a French company established a new factory in Adrian, Mich., adding 189 automotive jobs to an area accustomed to layoffs. In December, a British company bought a New Jersey maker of cough syrup.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Louise Story

articles.headline: An Iraq Veteran’s Descent; a Prosecutor’s Choice
articles.snippet: Walter R. Smith’s identity as a psychologically injured veteran shaped how a murder he committed was handled.
articles.abstract: Walter R. Smith’s identity as a psychologically injured veteran shaped how a murder he committed was handled.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOOELE, Utah  Not long after Lance Cpl. Walter Rollo Smith returned from Iraq, the Marines dispatched him to Quantico, Va., for a marksmanship instructor course.

articles.headline: No Quick Knockouts as Races Move to New Terrain
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain won South Carolina and New Hampshire, but the contests ahead are less tailored to his  needs.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain won South Carolina and New Hampshire, but the contests ahead are less tailored to his  needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C.  With his victory in South Carolina on Saturday, Senator John McCain of Arizona has accomplished what no other Republican presidential candidate has been able to do this year: he has captured two competitive contests. Not incidentally, this one was in the state that effectively sank his campaign in 2000.

articles.headline: Thumbs Race as Japan’s Best Sellers Go Cellular
articles.snippet: In Japan, cellphone novels have not only infiltrated the mainstream but have come to dominate it.
articles.abstract: In Japan, cellphone novels have not only infiltrated the mainstream but have come to dominate it.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Until recently, cellphone novels  composed on phone keypads by young women wielding dexterous thumbs and read by fans on their tiny screens  had been dismissed in Japan as a subgenre unworthy of the country that gave the world its first novel, “The Tale of Genji,” a millennium ago. Then last month, the year-end best-seller tally showed that cellphone novels, republished in book form, have not only infiltrated the mainstream but have come to dominate it.

articles.headline: The Legal Trail in a Delta Drama
articles.snippet: One of the nation’s best-known plaintiff’s lawyers, Richard Scruggs, is ensnared in a legal drama involving federal conspiracy and bribery charges.
articles.abstract: One of the nation’s best-known plaintiff’s lawyers, Richard Scruggs, is ensnared in a legal drama involving federal conspiracy and bribery charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: OXFORD, MISS.  ON a crisp, sunny morning last week, Mississippi’s political elite gathered in Jackson for a day of celebration. They began with a gospel prayer breakfast before proceeding to the state Capitol to witness the swearing-in of Haley Barbour for a second term as governor.

articles.headline: McCain Victory in South Carolina Caps Comeback
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain exorcised the ghosts of the attack-filled primary in the same state that derailed his campaign eight years ago.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain exorcised the ghosts of the attack-filled primary in the same state that derailed his campaign eight years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John McCain staved off a spirited challenge by Mike Huckabee to win the South Carolina primary on Saturday, exorcising the ghosts of the attack-filled primary here that derailed his presidential hopes eight years ago.
articles.byline: By MICHAEL COOPER and MEGAN THEE

articles.headline: Unscrambling the Alphabet of Fund Fees
articles.snippet: Mutual fund investors are right to wonder and worry about the costs they are paying to own their shares — $37 billion went into funds with loads in 2006.
articles.abstract: Mutual fund investors are right to wonder and worry about the costs they are paying to own their shares — $37 billion went into funds with loads in 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN stock markets climb, the fees associated with equity ownership are easy to shrug off. But with the stock market ailing in 2008  the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is down 9.75 percent as of Friday  mutual fund investors are right to wonder and worry about the costs they are paying to own their shares.

articles.headline: The Construction Site Called Saudi Arabia
articles.snippet: In a massive city of steel at the edge of the Red Sea, Saudi Arabia is trying to move beyond oil to become an industrial power.
articles.abstract: In a massive city of steel at the edge of the Red Sea, Saudi Arabia is trying to move beyond oil to become an industrial power.
articles.lead_paragraph: RABIGH, Saudi Arabia  THE alarm bell sounded the end of the lunch break here one November afternoon, and suddenly thousands of workers  on foot, on bicycles and in buses  streamed in, seemingly from out of nowhere, and jolted this huge construction site to life.

articles.headline: Vote of Women Propels Clinton in Nevada Caucus
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton won the vote, but Barack Obama won more delegates to the national convention.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton won the vote, but Barack Obama won more delegates to the national convention.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won the vote in the Nevada Democratic caucuses on Saturday, giving her a second consecutive victory in what is shaping up as a protracted battle with Senator Barack Obama.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Frontline Blogger Covers War in Iraq With a Soldier’s Eyes
articles.snippet: A former Special Forces soldier has created a loyal following on the Web with his accounts of frontline  soldiers’ daily work in Iraq.
articles.abstract: A former Special Forces soldier has created a loyal following on the Web with his accounts of frontline  soldiers’ daily work in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Yon was not a journalist, and he wasn’t sure what a blogger was. He had been in uniform but not in combat, and he wanted to keep it that way. He went to Iraq thinking he would stay for a month, and maybe find a way to write about the war after he got home.

articles.headline: The Video Game May Be Free, but to Be a Winner Can Cost Money
articles.snippet: In the next installment of its popular Battlefield series, Electronic Arts will charge only advertisers and the players who spring for extras.
articles.abstract: In the next installment of its popular Battlefield series, Electronic Arts will charge only advertisers and the players who spring for extras.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since John Riccitiello took over last year as chief executive of Electronic Arts, the video game industry bellwether, he has promised to revitalize the company with new games and new ways of reaching consumers. Now, that may be happening.

articles.headline: Republican Field Rides Full Force Into Florida Test
articles.snippet: The Republican presidential campaigns descended on Florida for the first primary in which all the candidates are fully participating.
articles.abstract: The Republican presidential campaigns descended on Florida for the first primary in which all the candidates are fully participating.
articles.lead_paragraph: POLK CITY, Fla.  The Republican presidential contest entered a new phase on Sunday as the campaigns descended on Florida for the first primary in which all the candidates are participating full force, using as their stage a state famous for divisive election battles.

articles.headline: Ex-Newsman Laments a Dying Craft
articles.snippet: The creator of “The Wire” writes a love letter to journalism, with the bosses cast as villains.
articles.abstract: The creator of “The Wire” writes a love letter to journalism, with the bosses cast as villains.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Something’s burning,” said one reporter to another, absently staring out the window at angry, thick black smoke rising over the city of Baltimore.

articles.headline: From MySpace to YourSpace
articles.snippet: A Web blockbuster is evolving to try to stay ahead of rivals.
articles.abstract: A Web blockbuster is evolving to try to stay ahead of rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Chris DeWolfe, the co-founder and chief executive of MySpace, was talking about international expansion with Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation bought the social networking site in 2005. According to Mr. DeWolfe, an entrepreneur used to moving at Internet velocity, he suggested that MySpace could expand to “four or five” countries in the next year.

articles.headline: For Clinton, Government as Economic Prod
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said government should take an active role in the economy to address the excesses of the market and of the Bush administration.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said government should take an active role in the economy to address the excesses of the market and of the Bush administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that if she became president, the federal government would take a more active role in the economy to address what she called the excesses of the market and of the Bush administration.

articles.headline: Getty Images Up for Sale, Could Fetch $1.5 Billion
articles.snippet: Getty Images, the world’s biggest supplier of pictures and video to media and advertising companies, has put itself on the auction block.
articles.abstract: Getty Images, the world’s biggest supplier of pictures and video to media and advertising companies, has put itself on the auction block.
articles.lead_paragraph: Getty Images, the world’s biggest supplier of pictures and video to media and advertising companies, has put itself on the auction block and could fetch more than $1.5 billion, people briefed on the situation said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Signs in Kenya That Killings Were Planned
articles.snippet: Some of the bloodletting that has left more than 650 people dead may have been premeditated and organized.
articles.abstract: Some of the bloodletting that has left more than 650 people dead may have been premeditated and organized.
articles.lead_paragraph: KERINGET, Kenya  At first the violence seemed as spontaneous as it was shocking, with machete-wielding mobs hacking people to death and burning women and children alive in a country that was celebrated as one of Africa’s most stable.
